	<item>
		<title>AZURE REST API &#038; PowerShell: Retrieve Cloud Service Configuration</title>
		<link>https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2015/06/02/azure-rest-api-powershell-retrieve-cloud-service-configuration/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 Jun 2015 06:00:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[djkaushal]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2015/06/02/azure-rest-api-powershell-retrieve-cloud-service-configuration/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Recently I was working on an issue where we had to retrieve <strong>PaaS</strong> instance configuration details like the RDP, OS Family, Reserved IP etc. Typically this is present in the <strong>.cscfg</strong> file of a Cloud Service.
</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">We had to retrieve these details via <strong>Azure Service Management REST API</strong>. Documentation on the <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/ee460812.aspx">Operations on Cloud Services</a> can be found on MSDN.
</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">The API of our interest is <strong>GET DEPLOYMENT</strong>. The documentation is available on MSDN: <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/ee460804.aspx">https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/ee460804.aspx</a>
		</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">In this post I will be using PowerShell scripts to invoke the <strong>GET DEPLOYMENT API</strong>. 
</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Below is a snippet from MSDN:
</span></p><div style="margin-left: 34pt"><table style="border-collapse:collapse; background: #e7e6e6" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:643px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-left:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-right:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt"><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">The <strong>Get Deployment</strong> request can be used to retrieve deployment events for a single deployment slot (staging or production) or for a specific deployment name. If you want to retrieve information by deployment name, you must first get the unique name for the deployment. This unique name is part of the response when you make a request to get the deployment in a deployment slot.</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">From MSDN documentation there are two ways to invoke the API. 
</span></p><div style="margin-left: 34pt"><table style="border-collapse:collapse" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:74px"/><col style="width:568px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr style="height: 25px; background: #0070c0"><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid 2.25pt; border-left:  solid 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p style="text-align: center"><span style="color:white; font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:12pt"><strong>Method</strong></span></p></td><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid 2.25pt; border-left:  none; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p style="text-align: center"><span style="color:white; font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:12pt"><strong>Request URI</strong></span></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 41px"><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  none; border-left:  solid 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid 1.0pt; border-right:  solid 1.0pt"><p style="text-align: center"><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">GET</span></p></td><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  none; border-left:  none; border-bottom:  solid 1.0pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p><a href="https://management.core.windows.net/&lt;subscription-id&gt;/services/hostedservices/&lt;cloudservice-name&gt;/deploymentslots/&lt;deployment-slot"><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">https://management.core.windows.net/&lt;subscription-id&gt;/services/hostedservices/&lt;cloudservice-name&gt;/deploymentslots/&lt;deployment-slot</span></a><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">&gt; </span></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 41px"><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  none; border-left:  solid 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 1.0pt"><p style="text-align: center"><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">GET</span></p></td><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  none; border-left:  none; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p><a href="https://management.core.windows.net/&lt;subscription-id&gt;/services/hostedservices/&lt;cloudservice-name&gt;/deployments/&lt;deployment-name"><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">https://management.core.windows.net/&lt;subscription-id&gt;/services/hostedservices/&lt;cloudservice-name&gt;/deployments/&lt;deployment-name</span></a><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">&gt; </span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">We already have a PowerShell commandlet for this functionality:<br/><strong>Get-AzureDeployment</strong>: <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dn495146.aspx">https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dn495146.aspx</a>
		</span></p><div><table style="border-collapse:collapse; background: #404040" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:756px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-top: 1px; padding-left: 7px; padding-bottom: 1px; padding-right: 7px"><p><span style="color:#00b0f0; font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:18pt">Requirements</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">In order to make an AZURE REST API call, you have to:
</span></p><ol><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Authenticate the request to Management Service. Refer this link: <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-in/library/azure/ee460782.aspx">https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-in/library/azure/ee460782.aspx</a>
			</span></li><li><div><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Some <strong>Azure Service Management REST API</strong>'s require additional headers to be sent along with the request. Read the documentation for the API before proceeding further.
</span></div><ol><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">The <strong>Get Deployment</strong> API requires the <strong>x-ms-version</strong> header in HTTP Request. Below is the snippet of the documentation for this API from MSDN.
</span></li></ol></li></ol><div style="margin-left: 34pt"><table style="border-collapse:collapse" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:143px"/><col style="width:499px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr style="height: 25px; background: #0070c0"><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid 2.25pt; border-left:  solid 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p style="text-align: center"><span style="color:white; font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:12pt"><strong>Request Header</strong></span></p></td><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid 2.25pt; border-left:  none; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p style="text-align: center"><span style="color:white; font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:12pt"><strong>Description</strong></span></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 41px"><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  none; border-left:  solid 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p style="text-align: center"><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">x-ms-version</span></p></td><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  none; border-left:  none; border-bottom:  solid 2.25pt; border-right:  solid 2.25pt"><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Required. Specifies the version of the operation to use for this request. This header should be set to <span style="background-color:yellow"><strong>2009-10-01</strong> or higher</span>. For more information about versioning headers, see <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/gg592580.aspx">Service Management Versioning</a>.</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p>
 </p><div><table style="border-collapse:collapse; background: #404040" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:756px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-top: 1px; padding-left: 7px; padding-bottom: 1px; padding-right: 7px"><p><span style="color:#00b0f0; font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:18pt">Generating the certificate</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">We will use <strong>MakeCert.exe</strong>. You may want to refer these articles:
</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt"><strong>Create &amp; Upload a Management Certificate for Azure</strong>: <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/gg551722.aspx">https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/gg551722.aspx</a>
			<br/><strong>Makecert.exe (Certificate Creation Tool)</strong>: <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bfsktky3(v=vs.110).aspx">https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bfsktky3(v=vs.110).aspx</a>
		</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Open a Visual studio command prompt and execute the following command:
</span></p><div style="margin-left: 34pt"><table style="border-collapse:collapse; background: #e7e6e6" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:747px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-left:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-right:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt"><p><span style="color:black; font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt"><span style="background-color:yellow">makecert -sky exchange -r -n "CN=</span><span style="background-color:lime">&lt;CertificateName&gt;</span><span style="background-color:yellow">" -pe -a sha1 -len 2048 -ss My "</span><span style="background-color:lime">&lt;CertificateName&gt;</span><span style="background-color:yellow">.cer"</span><span style="color:white">
								</span></span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:9pt">Replace the highlighted section (in green) in the above command with your inputs</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><ul><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Browse to Visual Studio Tools folder.
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Typically this is under: "<strong>C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Microsoft Visual Studio 2012\Visual Studio Tools</strong>"
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Double click and launch "<strong>VS2012 x86 Native Tools Command Prompt</strong>" in administrator mode
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Execute the above command as shown below:<br/><img src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/MSDNBlogsFS/prod.evol.blogs.msdn.com/CommunityServer.Blogs.Components.WeblogFiles/00/00/01/38/03/metablogapi/7444.060315_0550_AZURERESTAP1.png" original-url="http://blogs.msdn.com/cfs-file.ashx/__key/communityserver-blogs-components-weblogfiles/00-00-01-38-03-metablogapi/7444.060315_5F00_0550_5F00_AZURERESTAP1.png" alt=""/>
			</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Go to run and type "<strong>mmc</strong>" and then click on <strong>OK</strong>.
</span></li><li><span style="font-size:10pt"><span style="font-family:Segoe UI">Select <strong>File</strong>
				</span><span style="font-family:Wingdings">à</span><span style="font-family:Segoe UI">
					<strong>Add/Remove Snap-in…</strong>
				</span></span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Select <strong>Certificates</strong> and click on <strong>Add &gt; </strong>button
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Under the <strong>Certificates snap-in</strong> select <strong>My user account</strong> and click on <strong>Finish</strong>.
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Click on <strong>OK</strong>. 
</span></li><li><div><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">This view is the <strong>current user certificate store</strong> as shown below
</span></div><p><img src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/MSDNBlogsFS/prod.evol.blogs.msdn.com/CommunityServer.Blogs.Components.WeblogFiles/00/00/01/38/03/metablogapi/8877.060315_0550_AZURERESTAP2.png" original-url="http://blogs.msdn.com/cfs-file.ashx/__key/communityserver-blogs-components-weblogfiles/00-00-01-38-03-metablogapi/8877.060315_5F00_0550_5F00_AZURERESTAP2.png" alt=""/><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">
				</span></p></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Export the certificate without the private key and store it on your hard drive.
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Now go to the <a href="https://manage.windowsazure.com/">Azure Management Portal</a>
			</span></li><li><div><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Scroll down to the <strong>SETTINGS</strong> section.
</span></div><p><img src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/MSDNBlogsFS/prod.evol.blogs.msdn.com/CommunityServer.Blogs.Components.WeblogFiles/00/00/01/38/03/metablogapi/8484.060315_0550_AZURERESTAP3.png" original-url="http://blogs.msdn.com/cfs-file.ashx/__key/communityserver-blogs-components-weblogfiles/00-00-01-38-03-metablogapi/8484.060315_5F00_0550_5F00_AZURERESTAP3.png" alt=""/><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">
				</span></p></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">In the centre pane, click on <strong>MANAGEMENT CERTIFICATES</strong> &amp; then click on <strong>UPLOAD</strong>.
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Select the certificate we exported and upload it.<br/><img src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/MSDNBlogsFS/prod.evol.blogs.msdn.com/CommunityServer.Blogs.Components.WeblogFiles/00/00/01/38/03/metablogapi/0486.060315_0550_AZURERESTAP4.png" original-url="http://blogs.msdn.com/cfs-file.ashx/__key/communityserver-blogs-components-weblogfiles/00-00-01-38-03-metablogapi/0486.060315_5F00_0550_5F00_AZURERESTAP4.png" alt=""/>
			</span></li><li><div><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Make a note of the Certificate thumbprint. 
</span></div><p>
 </p></li></ul><div><table style="border-collapse:collapse; background: #404040" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:756px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td vAlign="middle" style="padding-top: 1px; padding-left: 7px; padding-bottom: 1px; padding-right: 7px"><p><span style="color:#00b0f0; font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:18pt">Invoking the REST API</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Once the certificate has been generated and uploaded. We can write a PowerShell script to retrieve the same certificate from the store and pass it along with the REST API request.
</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">We will be using <strong>PowerShell</strong> to invoke the API and retrieve the details. 
</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Below is the <strong>PowerShell</strong> script to retrieve the certificate from the user store and pass it on to the <strong>Azure Service Management</strong> for authentication.
</span></p><div><table style="border-collapse:collapse" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:917px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-left:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-right:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt"><p style="background: white"><span style="color:darkgreen; font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt">#Request Headers required to invoke the GET DEPLOYMENT REST API<br/><span style="color:orangered">$method</span>
								<span style="color:darkgray">=</span>
								<span style="color:darkred">"GET"<br/><span style="color:orangered">$headerDate</span>
									<span style="color:darkgray">=</span> '2009-10-01'<br/><span style="color:orangered">$headers</span>
									<span style="color:darkgray">=</span> @{"x-ms-version"<span style="color:darkgray">=<span style="color:darkred">"<span style="color:orangered">$headerDate<span style="color:darkred">"</span>}</span>
										</span></span></span></span></p><p style="background: white"><span style="font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt"><span style="color:darkgreen">#Retrieving the subscription ID<br/><span style="color:orangered">$subID</span>
									<span style="color:darkgray">=</span> (<span style="color:blue">Get-AzureSubscription</span>
									<span style="color:navy">-Current</span>)<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>SubscriptionId   </span><br/><span style="color:orangered">$URI</span>
								<span style="color:darkgray">=</span>
								<a href="https://management.core.windows.net/$subID/services/hostedservices/kaushalz/deployments/4f006bb7d2874dd4895f77a97b7938d0">https://management.core.windows.net/$subID/services/hostedservices/kaushalz/deployments/4f006bb7d2874dd4895f77a97b7938d0</a><span style="color:darkred">
								</span></span></p><p style="background: white"><span style="color:darkgreen; font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt">#Retrieving the certificate from Local Store<br/><span style="color:orangered">$cert</span>
								<span style="color:darkgray">=</span> (<span style="color:blue">Get-ChildItem</span>
								<span style="color:blueviolet">Cert:\CurrentUser\My</span>
								<span style="color:darkgray">|</span>
								<span style="color:blue">?</span>{<span style="color:orangered">$_<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>Thumbprint <span style="color:darkgray">-eq</span>
									<span style="color:darkred">"B4D460D985F1D07A6B9F8BFD67E36BC53A4490FC"</span>})<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>GetRawCertData()<span style="color:darkred">
									</span></span></span></p><p style="background: white"><span style="color:darkgreen; font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt">#converting the raw cert data to BASE64<br/><span style="color:orangered">body</span>
								<span style="color:darkgray">=</span>
								<span style="color:darkred">"&lt;Binary&gt;-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----`n</span>$(<span style="color:darkgray">[<span style="color:teal">convert<span style="color:darkgray">]::</span>ToBase64String(<span style="color:orangered">$cert</span>))<span style="color:darkred">`n-----END CERTIFICATE-----&lt;/Binary&gt;"
</span></span></span></span></p><p style="background: white"><span style="font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt"><span style="color:darkgreen">#Retrieving the certificate ThumbPrint<br/><span style="color:orangered">$mgmtCertThumb</span>
									<span style="color:darkgray">=</span> (<span style="color:blue">Get-AzureSubscription</span>
									<span style="color:navy">-Current</span>)<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>Certificate<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>Thumbprint</span>
							</span></p><p style="background: white"><span style="color:darkgreen; font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt">#Passing all the above parameters to Invoke-RestMethod cmdlet<br/><span style="color:blue">Invoke-RestMethod</span>
								<span style="color:navy">-Uri</span>
								<span style="color:orangered">$URI</span>
								<span style="color:navy">-Method</span>
								<span style="color:orangered">$method</span>
								<span style="color:navy">-Headers</span>
								<span style="color:orangered">$headers</span>
								<span style="color:navy">-CertificateThumbprint</span>
								<span style="color:darkred">" B4D460D985F1D07A6B9F8BFD67E36BC53A4490FC"</span>
								<span style="color:navy">-ContentType</span>
								<span style="color:orangered">$ContentType</span></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><ul><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Launch <strong>Windows PowerShell ISE</strong> in administrator mode.
</span></li><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Copy the above sample script and paste it in the scripting window.
</span></li></ul><div style="margin-left: 34pt"><table style="border-collapse:collapse; background: #e7e6e6" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:643px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-left:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-right:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt"><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt"><strong>NOTE</strong>: replace the <strong>thumbprint</strong> in the above script with the thumbprint of your certificate. You can retrieve this from the MMC windows we accessed earlier. I'm passing the <strong>Deployment Name</strong> (or <strong>Deployment ID</strong>) in the above URL.</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><ul><li><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Run the script to get the output as shown below:
</span></li></ul><p><img src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/MSDNBlogsFS/prod.evol.blogs.msdn.com/CommunityServer.Blogs.Components.WeblogFiles/00/00/01/38/03/metablogapi/3482.060315_0550_AZURERESTAP5.png" original-url="http://blogs.msdn.com/cfs-file.ashx/__key/communityserver-blogs-components-weblogfiles/00-00-01-38-03-metablogapi/3482.060315_5F00_0550_5F00_AZURERESTAP5.png" alt=""/><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">
		</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">If you read the documentation, the response body is in XML format and it is displaying only the parent node (DEPLOYMENT). 
</span></p><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">We can read the response into a XML object and then display it. Here is sample snippet:
</span></p><div style="margin-left: 34pt"><table style="border-collapse:collapse" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:690px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-left:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-right:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt"><p style="background: white"><span style="color:darkgreen; font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt">#Getting the response from the REST API and saving it as a XML object<br/><span style="color:darkgray">[<span style="color:teal">xml<span style="color:darkgray">]<span style="color:orangered">$url</span> =</span>
										<span style="color:blue">Invoke-RestMethod</span>
										<span style="color:navy">-Uri</span>
										<span style="color:orangered">$URI</span>
										<span style="color:navy">-Method</span>
										<span style="color:orangered">$method</span>
										<span style="color:navy">-Headers</span>
										<span style="color:orangered">$headers</span>
										<span style="color:navy">-CertificateThumbprint</span>
										<span style="color:darkred">"B4D460D985F1D07A6B9F8BFD67E36BC53A4490FC"</span>
										<span style="color:navy">-ContentType</span>
										<span style="color:orangered">$ContentType<span style="color:darkgreen">
											</span></span></span></span></span></p><p style="background: white"><span style="color:darkgreen; font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt">#Printing the XML<br/><span style="color:blue">write</span>
								<span style="color:orangered">$url<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>ChildNodes</span></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">Below is a screenshot of the output after adding the above two lines in the earlier script:
</span></p><p><img src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/MSDNBlogsFS/prod.evol.blogs.msdn.com/CommunityServer.Blogs.Components.WeblogFiles/00/00/01/38/03/metablogapi/1667.060315_0550_AZURERESTAP6.png" original-url="http://blogs.msdn.com/cfs-file.ashx/__key/communityserver-blogs-components-weblogfiles/00-00-01-38-03-metablogapi/1667.060315_5F00_0550_5F00_AZURERESTAP6.png" alt=""/><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">
		</span></p><div style="margin-left: 34pt"><table style="border-collapse:collapse; background: white" border="0"><colgroup><col style="width:643px"/></colgroup><tbody valign="top"><tr><td style="padding-left: 7px; padding-right: 7px; border-top:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-left:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-bottom:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt; border-right:  solid #00b0f0 2.25pt"><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt"><strong>NOTE</strong>: The Configuration section in the above output is a Base-64 encoded string. You would have to add the following snippet to parse this further:
</span></p><p style="background: white"><span style="font-family:Courier New; font-size:9pt"><span style="color:orangered">$base64encodedconfiguration</span>
								<span style="color:darkgray">=</span>
								<span style="color:orangered">$url<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>Deployment<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>Configuration</span><br/><span style="color:orangered">$d<span style="color:darkgray">=</span>
									<span style="color:darkgray">[<span style="color:teal">System.Convert<span style="color:darkgray">]::</span>FromBase64String(<span style="color:orangered">$base64encodedconfiguration</span>)</span><br/>[<span style="color:teal">xml<span style="color:darkgray">]<span style="color:orangered">$decodedxml</span> =</span>
											<span style="color:darkgray">[<span style="color:teal">System.Text.Encoding<span style="color:darkgray">]::</span>UTF8<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>GetString(<span style="color:orangered">$d</span>)</span><br/><span style="color:blue">write</span>
												<span style="color:orangered">$decodedxml<span style="color:darkgray">.</span>ChildNodes</span></span></span></span></span></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p><span style="font-family:Segoe UI; font-size:10pt">You can use the same approach to call any other Azure Service Management REST API. Ensure you read the documentation carefully and then proceed further.
</span></p><p><span style="font-size:10pt"><span style="font-family:Segoe UI">HTH </span><span style="font-family:Wingdings">J</span></span></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>HTML Table with horizontal &#038; vertical scrolling</title>
		<link>https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2017/06/13/html-table-with-horizontal-vertical-scrolling/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 13 Jun 2017 14:08:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[djkaushal]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/?p=931</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui">I blog very frequently and sometimes the posts contain code snippets. The site template sometimes limits the available real-estate and this can cause certain issues. If there is long text in one line, then they are stripped and will not be visible.<br></span></p> <p><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui">The solution to this is to:<br></span></p> <ul> <li><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui">Use a template which provides more real-estate.<br><strong>OR</strong></span>  <li><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui">Use a scrollable HTML table.</span></li></ul> <p><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui">If you chose the second option of a scrollable HTML table, below is a sample code-snippet that you can use to achieve this. The below snippet provides horizontal scrolling only. You can modify the same to achieve vertical scrolling<br></span></p> <blockquote> <script src="https://gist.github.com/anonymous/91aa562dbb28311f66122f89a3e088a0.js"></script> </blockquote> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui">This is how it looks in different browsers:</span></p> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/06/image360.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/06/image_thumb342.png" width="645" height="531"></a><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui"><br></span></p></blockquote><span style="font-size: 10pt;font-family: segoe ui"> <p>&nbsp;</p></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Azure Web Apps: How to retrieve user email in the claim when using Microsoft Account as a provider in Easy Auth</title>
		<link>https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2016/04/01/azure-web-apps-how-to-retrieve-user-email-in-the-claim-when-using-microsoft-account-as-a-provider-in-easy-auth/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Apr 2016 10:33:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[djkaushal]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/?p=1021</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-in/azure/app-service/app-service-authentication-overview?toc=%2fazure%2fapp-service-web%2ftoc.json"><strong>App Service Authentication/Authorization </strong></a>also known as<strong> Easy Auth</strong> is one of the widely used feature in <strong>Azure App Service</strong>. It reduces the burden on the developers and provides a way for the application to sign in users without changing code. It is implemented as a module and is injected at runtime within the app. It automates a lot of configuration which usually is a tedious task. It is a one time process where the users have to configure the web app to use one or more of the identity providers. Following is a list of providers currently supported with this module:
</span></span>
<ul>
 	<li><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>Azure Active Directory (AAD)</strong> </span></span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>Facebook</strong> </span></span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>Google</strong> </span></span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>Twitter</strong> </span></span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>Microsoft Account (microsoftaccount)</strong> </span></span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Refer the following article to configure your web application to use Microsoft account as the auth provider.
</span>
<p style="padding-left: 30px"><a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-in/azure/app-service-mobile/app-service-mobile-how-to-configure-microsoft-authentication?toc=%2fazure%2fapp-service-web%2ftoc.json" title="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/app-service-mobile-how-to-configure-microsoft-authentication/"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">How to configure your App Service application to use Microsoft Account login</span></a><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"> </span></p>
<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Multiple providers can be configured for a single web app. For this, in portal set the</span>

<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">"<strong>Action to take when request is not authenticated</strong>"<strong> </strong>= “<strong>Allow request (no action)</strong>”. </span>

<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">This is also known as <strong>deferred authentication</strong>. In this case the providers from the app have to be called explicitly and the application will consume it based on the obtained claim. The following table illustrates the api endpoint which is used to invoke certain calls.  </span>
<table style="height: 110px;margin-left: 50px;background-color: #00bdff;border-style: solid;border-color: #0775BD" width="597" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="3">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="128" valign="top"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><strong><span style="color: #ffffff"> <span style="color: #000000">Login End Point</span></span></strong></span></td>
<td width="465">  <span style="font-size: small;font-family: consolas;color: #0000ff;background-color: #ffffff"><span style="color: #000000">/.auth/login/</span><span style="color: #c0504d">&lt;provider&gt;<span style="font-family: Consolas;font-size: small"> </span></span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="132" valign="top"></td>
<td width="472" valign="top"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">  <span style="font-family: consolas;color: #0000ff;background-color: #ffffff"><span style="color: #000000">/.auth/login/</span><span style="color: #c0504d">&lt;provider<span style="color: #000000">&gt;</span></span><span style="color: #000000">?post_login_redirect_uri=</span><span style="color: #c0504d">&lt;url-path&gt;<span style="font-family: Consolas;font-size: small"> </span></span></span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="133" valign="top"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><strong><span style="color: #ffffff"> <span style="color: #000000">Logout End point</span></span></strong></span></td>
<td width="473" valign="top">  <span style="color: #000000;font-family: consolas;font-size: small;background-color: #ffffff">/.auth/logout<span style="font-family: Consolas;font-size: small"> </span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="134" valign="top"></td>
<td width="473" valign="top"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">  <span style="font-family: consolas;color: #0000ff;background-color: #ffffff"><span style="color: #000000">/.auth/logout?post_logout_redirect_uri</span><span style="color: #c0504d"><span style="color: #000000">=</span>&lt;url-path&gt;<span style="font-family: Consolas;font-size: small"> </span></span></span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="134" valign="top"><strong><span style="color: #ffffff;font-family: Segoe UI;font-size: small"> <span style="color: #000000">Token Access</span></span></strong></td>
<td width="473" valign="top">  <span style="color: #000000;font-family: consolas;font-size: small;background-color: #ffffff">/.auth/me<span style="font-family: Consolas;font-size: small"> </span></span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="padding-left: 30px"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><strong><span style="font-family: consolas;color: #0000ff;background-color: #cccccc">&lt;providers&gt;</span></strong> can be set to <strong>aad</strong>, <strong>facebook</strong>, <strong>google</strong>, <strong>twitter </strong>&amp; <strong>microsoftaccount</strong>. Here is an example:</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px"><a href="https://easyauth.kaushalz.com/.auth/login/microsoftaccount?post_login_redirect_url=/" title="https://easyauth.kaushalz.com/.auth/login/microsoftaccount?post_login_redirect_url=/"><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small">https://easyauth.kaushalz.com/.auth/login/<span style="background-color: #ffff00">microsoftaccount</span>?<span style="background-color: #ffff00">post_login_redirect_url=/</span></span></span></a></p>

<table style="height: 55px;margin-left: 50px" width="610" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="3">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="529" valign="top"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>NOTE</strong></span></span>:<em> The query string parameter</em> <span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-family: consolas;color: #0000ff;background-color: #cccccc">post_login_redirect_uri</span></span> <em>redirects the user request to the value specified in url path. </em></span><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><em>In the above example url, post successful authentication, the users will be redirected to the root of the application</em>.
</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h1>Adding users email address to the Claim<span style="font-family: segoe ui"></span></h1>
<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">By default, the claim which is obtained from <strong>Microsoft Account</strong> provider doesn’t contain the users email address. Here is a how the default user claims obtained from MSA looks like</span>
<p style="padding-left: 60px"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image37.png"><img style="padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-width: 0px" title="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image_thumb36.png" alt="image" width="605" border="0" height="583" /></a></p>
<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">To add the email address as part of the claim the following scopes have to be enabled:</span>
<ul>
 	<li><strong><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">wl.basic </span></strong></li>
 	<li><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>wl.emails</strong> </span></span></li>
</ul>
<table style="height: 29px;margin-left: 50px" width="610" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="3">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="494" valign="top"><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>NOTE</strong>: The token can be obtain by calling the following endpoint <span style="font-family: consolas;color: #0000ff;background-color: #cccccc">/.auth/me</span></span></span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Refer the following steps on how to configure this via the Azure portal
</span>
<ul>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Log-in to Azure portal: </span><a href="https://portal.azure.com"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">https://portal.azure.com</span></a><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"> </span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Click on <strong>App Service</strong> &amp; select the web app
</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Under <strong>Settings</strong> blade, click on <strong>Authentication/Authorization</strong> (This will launch another blade for this feature</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">In here, configure the following
</span>
<ol>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Set App Service Authentication to <strong>On</strong></span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Under Authentication providers, click on <strong>Microsoft Account</strong>.</span></li>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Click on <strong> <span style="color: #0000ff"><span style="font-family: consolas;background-color: #cccccc">wl.basic</span></span> &amp; <span style="color: #0000ff"><span style="font-family: consolas;background-color: #cccccc">wl.emails</span></span></strong> to enable them </span><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">(Refer the following screenshot)</span></li>
</ol>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image38.png"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><img style="padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;margin: 1px;padding-right: 0px;border-width: 0px" title="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image_thumb37.png" alt="image" width="1020" border="0" height="847" /></span></a></p>

<ul>
 	<li><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Click on <strong>OK</strong> and then click on <strong>Save</strong>. </span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">When the users try to login again, the application will notify the user that it needs permissions so that the application can retrieve users email address. This happens for the first time.
</span>
<p style="padding-left: 60px"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image40.png"><img style="padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-width: 0px" title="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image_thumb39.png" alt="image" width="415" border="0" height="446" /></a></p>
<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">Upon giving permissions to the application, the <strong>users email address</strong> becomes part of the <strong>user_claims</strong>. Below is a screenshot for reference:</span>
<p style="padding-left: 60px"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image39.png"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><img style="padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-width: 0px" title="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/04/image_thumb38.png" alt="image" width="681" border="0" height="796" /></span></a></p>

<table style="height: 24px;margin-left: 50px" width="610" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="3">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="494" valign="top"><span style="font-family: segoe ui"><span style="font-size: small"><strong>NOTE</strong>: I used Chrome browser with the <strong>JSON Formatter </strong>extension installed to see the claim </span></span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
&nbsp;

<span style="text-decoration: underline"><strong><span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">MORE INFORMATION:</span></strong></span>

<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui">In case the application is not hosted on Azure App Service, please refer the following thread on Stackoverflow on how to do this for your application.</span>

<span style="font-size: small;font-family: segoe ui"><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17168353/getting-email-from-oauth-authentication-microsoft?lq=1">http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17168353/getting-email-from-oauth-authentication-microsoft?lq=1</a><strong>
</strong></span>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Azure App Service: How to connect to the Kudu site of a specific instance</title>
		<link>https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2016/11/21/azure-app-service-how-to-connect-to-the-kudu-site-of-a-specific-instance/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Nov 2016 06:51:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[djkaushal]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/?p=1405</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><font size="2">Every Azure Web App has an associated 'scm' service site, which runs Kudu and other </font><a href="https://github.com/projectkudu/kudu/wiki/Azure-Site-Extensions"><font size="2">Site Extensions</font></a><font size="2">. </font> <div><font size="2"><font size="4"><font face="Segoe UI Semibold"><u>OVERVIEW</u></font>:</font> </font></div> <ul> <li><font size="2">Kudu site can be accessed using either of these credentials</font>  <ul> <li><font size="2">Single Sign-on</font>  <li><font size="2">User-level credentials (aka Deployment Credentials)</font>  <li><font size="2">Site-level credentials&nbsp; (aka Publish Profile Credentials)</font></li></ul> <li><font size="2">Kudu site always connect to a single instance. E.g. If the site is hosted in an App Service plan which is scaled out to 3 instances, then at any time the KUDU will always connect to one instance only.</font></li></ul> <p>Here is a simple request flow of an Azure Web App  <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image503.png"><img title="image" style="border-top: 0px;border-right: 0px;border-bottom: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;border-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image_thumb418.png" width="616" height="340"></a></p></blockquote> <p><font size="2">The front-end uses <b>ARRAffinity</b> cookie to affinitize the request to specific instances. This cookie can be disabled if needed. Refer </font><a href="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/blog/disabling-arrs-instance-affinity-in-windows-azure-web-sites/"><font size="2">this</font></a><font size="2"> on how disable ARR Affinity. </font> <div><font size="2">The <b>ARRAffinity</b> cookie is unique and corresponds to an instance. If there are multiple instances, then there will be <b>ARRAffinity</b> cookie corresponding to those many instances.</font> <font size="2">So we can modify the <b>ARRAffinity</b> cookie in the HTTP response and force KUDU to connect to a specific instance. </font></div> <div>&nbsp;</div> <div><font size="2"><font size="4"><font face="Segoe UI Semibold"><u>PRE-REQUISITES</u></font>:</font> </font></div> <ul> <li><font size="2"><strong>Browser</strong>: Chrome/Firefox/Opera or any other browser which has extensions that allows you to edit cookies.</font>  <li><font size="2"><strong>Extension</strong>: <a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/editthiscookie/fngmhnnpilhplaeedifhccceomclgfbg?hl=en">EditThisCookie (Chrome)</a> | <a title="https://addons.opera.com/en/extensions/details/edit-this-cookie/" href="https://addons.opera.com/en/extensions/details/edit-this-cookie/">EditThisCookie (Opera)</a></font></li></ul> <p><u><font size="4" face="Segoe UI Semibold">DETERMINE THE ARRAFFINITY COOKIE OF AN INSTANCE</font> </u> <ul> <li><font size="2">Browse to </font><a href="https://resources.azure.com/"><font size="2">https://resources.azure.com/</font></a><font size="2"> (Azure Resource Explorer) </font> <li><font size="2">In the search window enter the name of the web app. See the following screenshot for reference:</font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image504.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image_thumb419.png" width="1028" height="487"></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">If there are other Azure resources with similar names, select the resource of type “<b>Microsoft.Web/sites</b>” </font> <li><font size="2">In the left side panel, expand “<b>instances</b>” and this would load all the instances on which the web app is hosted. The instance name displayed is also the value of the <strong>ARRAffinity</strong> cookie. </font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image505.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image_thumb420.png" width="1026" height="498"></a></p></blockquote> <p><font size="2">In the above image the site kaushalp is scaled out to 2 instances. So we have 2 instance id’s which are beginning with:</font></p> <ol> <li><font size="2">bac64d </font> <li><font size="2">c2a879</font></li></ol> <p><u><font size="4" face="Segoe WP Semibold">CONNECT TO THE KUDU CONSOLE OF A SPECIFIC INSTANCE</font></u>  <ul> <li><font size="2">For this we need to have a tool which allows us to modify the cookies </font> <li><font size="2">There are multiple ways to do this. </font> <li><font size="2">I am using <b>EditThisCookie</b> extension in chrome browser. Here is the link to install this: </font><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/editthiscookie/fngmhnnpilhplaeedifhccceomclgfbg?hl=en"><font size="2">Install EditThisCookie</font></a><font size="2"> </font> <li><font size="2">Now, browse to the KUDU site of your web app: </font><a href="https://%3csitename%3e.scm.azurewebsites.net"><font size="2">https://&lt;sitename&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net</font></a><font size="2"> (<i>replace &lt;sitename&gt; with name of the web app</i>) </font> <li><font size="2">Click on <strong>Environment</strong>. </font> <li><font size="2">Under <b>System info</b>, the “<b>instance id</b>” value determines the instance to which the KUDU is connected. In the screenshot below, the kudu site is connected to the instance whose <strong>short instance id</strong> is <strong>bac64d</strong>.</font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image506.png"><font size="2"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image507.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image_thumb421.png" width="679" height="258"></a></font></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">We can use one of the instances value we obtained via <b>ARM explorer</b> to force KUDU to connect to a specific site. <br>(Here we are connecting to the instance with the id beginning with “<b>bac64d</b>” ) </font> <li><font size="2">In the browser window click on <b>EditThisCookie </b><b><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image005.gif"><img title="clip_image005" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;margin: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="clip_image005" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image005_thumb.gif" width="19" height="19"></a></b>&nbsp; icon (next to the <b>Address bar)</b>. </font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image00617.jpg"><font size="2"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image00618.jpg"><img title="clip_image006" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="clip_image006" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image006_thumb14.jpg" width="621" height="103"></a></font></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">In the pop-up, click on <strong>ARRAffinity</strong> </font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image0071.jpg"><font size="2"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image0072.jpg"><img title="clip_image007" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="clip_image007" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/clip_image007_thumb1.jpg" width="620" height="226"></a></font></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">Replace the value with the instance id that you need to connect to</font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image508.png"><font size="2"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image509.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2016/11/image_thumb422.png" width="591" height="525"></a></font></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">Click on the<strong> tick mark</strong> to save the cookie and then refresh the page. </font></li></ul> <p><font size="2">It should have connected to other instance. To confirm, browse to <strong>Environment </strong>and under <strong>System Info </strong>the value of Instance id should match the value that was entered earlier.</font></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Azure App Service: Using cURL for deployment</title>
		<link>https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2017/01/24/azure-app-service-using-curl-for-deployment/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Jan 2017 05:26:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[djkaushal]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/?p=1495</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>cURL</strong> is a command line tool that can be used to send or receive files. <span style="font-size: small">cURL.exe supports numerous protocols like HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, FTPS, SFTP, LDAP, TELNET, SMTP, POP3 etc. For more information please refer the below links:</span></p> <blockquote> <p><a title="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CURL" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CURL"><span style="font-size: small">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CURL</span></a><br><a title="https://curl.haxx.se/docs/" href="https://curl.haxx.se/docs/"><span style="font-size: small">https://curl.haxx.se/docs/</span></a></p></blockquote> <h2><span style="text-decoration: underline">Syntax</span></h2> <blockquote> <p><strong><span style="font-size: small;font-family: 'Courier New';background-color: #cccccc"> curl.exe -T &lt;path-to-file-that-needs-to-be-deployed&gt; -u "username:password" "FTP URL" </span></strong></p></blockquote> <p><span style="font-size: small">From curl documentation<br></span></p> <blockquote> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" width="476" border="2"> <tbody> <tr> <td bgcolor="#e0e0e0" valign="top" width="472"><span style="font-family: consolas"><span style="font-size: small">-<strong>T</strong>, --<strong>upload-file</strong> FILE Transfer FILE to destination</span><br></span><span style="font-family: consolas"><span style="font-size: small">--<strong>url</strong> URL URL to work with</span> </span><span style="font-family: consolas"><span style="font-size: small">-u, <strong>--user</strong> USER[:PASSWORD] Server user and password</span><br></span><span style="font-family: consolas"><span style="font-size: small">--<strong>tlsuser</strong> USER TLS username</span><br></span><span style="font-family: consolas"><span style="font-size: small">--<strong>tlspassword</strong> STRING TLS password</span><br></span><span style="font-size: small;font-family: consolas">--<strong>tlsauthtype</strong> STRING TLS authentication type (default SRP)</span></td></tr></tbody></table></blockquote> <h3><span style="text-decoration: underline"><font size="6" face="Segoe UI Semilight">Pre-Requisites:</font></span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-size: small">Deployment over <strong>FTPS</strong> will work only if the version of the curl is SSL aware. Download it from here:</span> </li></ul> <p><a href="https://curl.haxx.se/download.html"><span style="font-size: small">https://curl.haxx.se/download.html</span></a></p> <ul> <li><span style="font-size: small">FTP endpoint of the web app. You can get this from portal or from the publish profile of the web app (under FTP section search for publishURL)</span>  <li><span style="font-size: small">Username and password for authentication (Either deployment or publish profile credentials. See </span><a href="https://github.com/projectkudu/kudu/wiki/Deployment-credentials"><span style="font-size: small">this</span></a><span style="font-size: small">)</span>  <ul> <li><span style="font-size: small">With user-level credentials (User specific): sitename\username</span>  <li><span style="font-size: small">With site-level credentials (Site specific/publish profile) : sitename\$sitename</span> </li></ul></li></ul> <blockquote> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" width="731" border="2"> <tbody> <tr> <td bgcolor="#e0e0e0" valign="top" width="727"> <h4><span style="font-size: large;font-family: 'Segoe UI Semibold'">For FTPS<br></span></h4> <ul> <ul> <li><span style="font-size: small">Browse to the following location: </span><a href="http://curl.haxx.se/docs/caextract.html"><span style="font-size: small">http://curl.haxx.se/docs/caextract.html</span></a>  <li><span style="font-size: small">Right click and download the "cacert.pem" file and rename the file extension to ".crt" (Use Chrome)</span> </li></ul></ul></td></tr></tbody></table></blockquote> <h2><span style="text-decoration: underline"><span style="font-family: 'Segoe UI Semibold'"><font size="6" face="Segoe UI Semilight">Deploying via FTP</font></span></span></h2> <ul> <li><span style="font-size: small">Launch command prompt</span>  <li><span style="font-size: small">Browse to the folder location where curl was downloaded and execute the following command:</span> </li></ul> <blockquote> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" width="870" border="2"> <tbody> <tr> <td bgcolor="#a4a4a4" valign="top" width="907"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: consolas">C:\&gt;curl -T C:\sample.war -u "<span style="background-color: #00ff00">kaushalp\$kaushalp</span>:&lt;password&gt;" </span><a href="ftp://waws-prod-sg1-005.ftp.azurewebsites.windows.net/site/wwwroot/"><span style="font-size: small;font-family: consolas">ftp://waws-prod-sg1-005.ftp.azurewebsites.windows.net/site/wwwroot/</span></a><span style="font-family: consolas"> </span></td></tr></tbody></table></blockquote> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image603.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image_thumb521.png" width="876" height="161"></a></p></blockquote> <h2><span style="text-decoration: underline"><span style="font-family: 'Segoe UI Semibold'"><font size="6" face="Segoe UI Semilight">Deploying via FTPS</font></span></span></h2> <p><span style="font-size: small">While using <strong>cURL </strong>via FTPS (FTP over SSL), the following error may be encountered when trying to connect over HTTP.</span></p> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image604.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image_thumb522.png" width="790" height="365"></a></p></blockquote> <p><span style="font-size: small">The following error is seen because curl will try to verify the certificate received in the Server Hello and it fails as it couldn’t verify the CA who issued the certificate.</span></p> <p><span style="font-size: small">This problem can be addressed by using an additional parameter either <strong><span style="background-color: #ffff00">--cacert </span></strong>or <strong><span style="background-color: #ffff00">-k</span> </strong>can be specified.</span></p> <blockquote> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" width="798" border="2"> <tbody> <tr> <td bgcolor="#a4a4a4" valign="top" width="794"><span style="font-family: consolas"><span style="font-size: small">C:\&gt;curl -T C:\sample.war -u "<span style="background-color: #00ff00">kaushalp\$kaushalp</span>:&lt;password&gt;" ftps://waws-prod-sg1-005.ftp.azurewebsites.windows.net/site/wwwroot/ <span style="background-color: #ffff00">-k</span></span> </span></td></tr></tbody></table></blockquote> <p><span style="font-size: small"><strong><span style="background-color: #ffff00">-k, --insecure</span></strong> Allow connections to SSL sites without certs (H)</span></p> <blockquote> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" width="794" border="2"> <tbody> <tr> <td bgcolor="#a4a4a4" valign="top" width="790"><span style="font-family: consolas"><span style="font-size: small">C:\&gt;curl -T C:\sample.war -u "<span style="background-color: #00ff00">kaushalp\$kaushalp</span>:&lt;password&gt;" ftps://waws-prod-sg1-005.ftp.azurewebsites.windows.net/site/wwwroot/ <span style="background-color: #ffff00">--cacert e:\tools\kaushal-bundle.crt</span></span> </span></td></tr></tbody></table></blockquote> <p><span style="font-size: small"><strong><span style="background-color: #ffff00">--cacert</span></strong> FILE CA certificate to verify peer against (SSL)</span></p> <h1 align="center"><span style="text-decoration: underline"><span style="font-family: 'Segoe UI Semibold'"><font size="6" face="Segoe UI Semilight">TROUBLESHOOTING</font></span></span></h1> <p style="padding-left: 30px"><span style="font-size: small">Error: "<span style="color: #ff0000">curl: (25) Failed FTP upload: 550</span>"<br><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image605.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image_thumb523.png" width="903" height="149"><br></a>This error is seen when the FTP URL does not contain a trailing slash "/".</span></p> <h2><span style="text-decoration: underline"><span style="font-size: large">More Information:</span></span></h2> <p><span style="font-size: small">Here is the default list of CA's that are supported by curl: </span><a href="https://curl.haxx.se/ca/cacert.pem"><span style="font-size: small">https://curl.haxx.se/ca/cacert.pem</span></a><span style="font-size: small"> (This was the file that was downloaded under pre-requisites)</span></p> <p><span style="font-size: small">Users can generate their own crt file and pass it to CURL. </span></p> <p><span style="font-size: small"></span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1495</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2017-01-24 10:56:48]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2017-01-24 05:26:48]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

<meta property="og:title" content="Azure App Service: Using cURL for deployment" />

<meta property="og:site_name" content="Unleashed" />
<meta property="og:description" content="cURL is a command line tool that can be used to send or receive files. cURL.exe supports numerous protocols like HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, FTPS, SFTP, LDAP, TELNET, SMTP, POP3 etc. For more information please refer the below links: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CURL https://curl.haxx.se/docs/ Syntax  curl.exe -T &lt;path-to-file-that-needs-to-be-deployed&gt; -u &#8220;username:password&#8221; &#8220;FTP URL&#8221; From curl documentation &#8211;T, &#8212;upload-file FILE Transfer..." />
<meta property="og:image" content="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image_thumb521.png" />
<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary" />
<meta name="twitter:title" content="Azure App Service: Using cURL for deployment" />
<meta name="twitter:url" content="https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2017/01/24/azure-app-service-using-curl-for-deployment/" />

	<item>
		<title>Azure App Service: Manually collect memory dumps</title>
		<link>https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2017/05/04/azure-app-service-manually-collect-memory-dumps/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 04 May 2017 11:35:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[djkaushal]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/?p=1555</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><u></u></p> <p><font size="2">While troubleshooting web application performance issues we are sometimes required to gather memory dumps during the time of the issue.</font></p> <p><font size="2">In <font face="Segoe UI Semibold">Azure App Service</font>, we do not have RDP access to the machines. However, this doesn’t restrict us from gathering logs &amp; data for troubleshooting. I am listing out few methods using which we can generate memory dumps of the process during the time of the issue.</font></p> <h1><u>Method 1: Using ProcDump.exe </u></h1> <blockquote> <h5><font size="2"><u><font face="Segoe UI Semibold">Pre-Requisite</font>:</u> For this we need the sysinternals utility: </font><a href="https://live.sysinternals.com/procdump.exe" target="_blank"><font size="2">ProcDump.exe</font></a></h5></blockquote> <p><font size="2">Azure App Service instances include the sysinternals suite in the default image. They can be located here via the KUDU console: <font style="background-color: #cccccc" face="Consolas">D:\devtools\sysinternals</font></font></p> <p><font size="2">The users may also download ProcDump from </font><a href="https://live.sysinternals.com/procdump.exe" target="_blank"><font size="2">here</font></a><font size="2"> and upload it a specific location such as <font style="background-color: #cccccc" face="Consolas">D:\home\LogFiles\Dumps</font> and use it. </font></p> <ul> <li><font size="2">Browse to the KUDU console </font> <li><font size="2">Click on <strong>Process Explorer</strong> menu. </font> <li><font size="2">There will be 2 w3wp.exe processes, one for <strong>SCM </strong>(KUDU) and another for the application. </font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image121.png"><img title="image" style="border-top: 0px;border-right: 0px;border-bottom: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;border-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image_thumb122.png" width="798" height="171"></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">Note the <strong>PID </strong>(Process ID) of the w3wp.exe corresponding to the application (see the image above) </font> <li><font size="2">Browse to <strong>Debug Console </strong>–&gt; <strong>CMD</strong> </font> <li><font size="2">In the command window, navigate to the <strong>dumps </strong>folder. </font> <li><font size="2">Execute the following command to generate a full memory dump of the process</font></li></ul> <blockquote> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" width="620" border="2"> <tbody> <tr> <td bgcolor="#e5f9ff" valign="top" width="616"><font size="2" face="Courier New">procdump.exe -accepteula –ma &lt;PID of the process&gt;</font></td></tr> <tr> <td bgcolor="#e5f9ff" valign="top" width="616"><font size="2">where, <br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -ma&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Write a dump file with all process memory. The default dump format only includes <br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; thread and handle information<br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -accepteula&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Use this switch to automatically accept the Sysinternals license agreement.</font></td></tr></tbody></table></blockquote> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image630.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/01/image_thumb547.png" width="804" height="506"></a></p></blockquote> <h1><u>Method 2: Using Diagnostics as a Service (DaaS) </u></h1> <h2><font size="4"><font face="Segoe UI"><u>Via Portal:</u></font></font></h2> <ul> <li><font size="2">Login to Azure portal. (</font><a href="https://portal.azure.com"><font size="2">https://portal.azure.com</font></a><font size="2">) </font> <li><font size="2">Select the Azure Web App that you intend to troubleshoot </font> <li><font size="2">Click on <strong>Diagnose and solve problems</strong>.</font> </li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image59.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;margin: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image_thumb62.png" width="232" height="272"></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">In the new blade click on <strong>Diagnostics as a Service</strong>. (<em>Bottom right side of the blade.</em>)</font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image60.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;margin: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image_thumb63.png" width="258" height="311"></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li>In the new blade, set the following:  <ul> <li><strong>Application Type </strong>– Depending on the type of application set the value to <strong>ASP.NET </strong>or <strong>PHP </strong>or <strong>Node.js</strong>.  <li><strong>Diagnosers </strong>– Since this post is about collecting memory dumps, ensure that the check box against <strong>Memory Dump </strong>is selected. If you need <strong>Event Viewer Logs </strong>&amp; <strong>Http Logs</strong> then you can enable them too.  <li><strong>Instances – </strong>If the App Service Plan is configured to use more than one instance, then you can configure this to collect the logs on either multiple instance or specific instances.</li></ul></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image61.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;margin: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image_thumb64.png" width="561" height="310"></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li>Click on Run to collect the logs. The blade will indicate the status of the operation and will also run analysis on the collected data. </li></ul> <ul> <li>This puts the data under <strong><font style="background-color: #cccccc" size="2" face="Consolas">D:\home\data\DaaS\Logs<font style="background-color: #ffffff"> </font></font></strong>folder.<!--EndFragment--> </li></ul> <p><font size="4"><font face="Segoe UI"><u>Via KUDU:</u></font></font></p> <p><font size="2">In scenarios, where the user may not have access to the portal, they can use <strong>Kudu </strong>to access <strong>DaaS</strong>. The option to select instances is not available here as KUDU by default connects to a specific instance. You can refer my previous post on this: </font><a title="https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2016/11/21/azure-app-service-how-to-connect-to-the-kudu-site-of-a-specific-instance/" href="https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2016/11/21/azure-app-service-how-to-connect-to-the-kudu-site-of-a-specific-instance/"><font size="2">How to connect to the Kudu site of a specific instance</font></a></p> <ul> <li><font size="2">Login to the <strong>KUDU</strong> console and append /<strong>daas</strong> to the path. (</font><a href="http://&lt;yoursitename&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net/daas"><font size="2">http://&lt;yoursitename&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net/daas</font></a><font size="2">) </font> <li><font size="2">This will launch the <strong>DaaS</strong> portal </font> <li><font size="2">Reproduce the issue </font> <li><font size="2">Click on <strong>Diagnose Now </strong>button as shown below:</font></li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image62.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;margin: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image_thumb65.png" width="877" height="453"></a></p></blockquote> <ul> <li>This will initiate logs collect.  <li>You can click on Schedule Analysis to select the logs that will be collected and whether you want to run an analysis on that. </li></ul> <blockquote> <h4><font size="4"><u>More Information:</u></font></h4> <p><a title="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/blog/daas/" href="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/blog/daas/"><font size="2">DaaS – Diagnostics as a Service for Azure Web Sites</font></a></p> <p><a title="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/blog/new-updates-to-daas-diagnostics-as-a-service-for-azure-websites/" href="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/blog/new-updates-to-daas-diagnostics-as-a-service-for-azure-websites/"><font size="2">New Updates to DaaS - Diagnostics as a Service for Azure Websites</font></a><font size="2">&nbsp;</font></p> <p><a title="https://sunithamk.wordpress.com/2015/11/04/diagnose-and-mitigate-issues-with-azure-web-apps-support-portal/" href="https://sunithamk.wordpress.com/2015/11/04/diagnose-and-mitigate-issues-with-azure-web-apps-support-portal/"><font size="2">https://sunithamk.wordpress.com/2015/11/04/diagnose-and-mitigate-issues-with-azure-web-apps-support-portal/</font></a>&nbsp;</p></blockquote> <h1><u>Method 3: Using Process Explorer (KUDU) (<em>least favorable</em>)</u></h1> <p><font face="Segoe UI Semibold"><font size="2"><font style="background-color: #ffff00" color="#c0504d">This method is the least favorable as it generates the memory dump and the prompts the user to download it. If the download is interrupted due to some reason then the data is lost.</font> </font></font></p> <ul> <li>Login to the KUDU console. (<a href="http://%3cyoursitename%3e.scm.azurewebsites.net">http://&lt;yoursitename&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net</a>)  <li>Click on <strong>Process Explorer</strong> menu  <li>There will be 2 w3wp.exe processes, one for <strong>SCM </strong>(KUDU) and another for the application.  <li>Reproduce the issue  <li>Right click the w3wp process (<em>without the <strong>scm </strong>tag</em>) and select <strong>Download memory dump</strong> –&gt; <strong>Full Dump</strong> as shown below:</li></ul> <blockquote> <p><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/clip_image0012.jpg"><img title="clip_image001" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="clip_image001" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/clip_image001_thumb1.jpg" width="1028" height="221"></a> </p></blockquote> <ul> <li><font size="2">Depending on the size of the process it will take couple of seconds or few minutes to generate the dump on the VM and prompt you to download the file</font></li></ul> <h3 align="center"><u><font color="#ff0000" size="4" face="Segoe UI Semibold">****IMPORTANT****</font></u></h3> <ul> <li> <div align="left"><font size="2">Using <strong>Daas </strong>via portal is the preferable method. When the web app is scaled out to run on more than one instance, then you can use DaaS to collect the memory dump from a specific instance. <strong>Method 2 &amp; 3 </strong>will generate memory dump on a specific instance and is not fool proof as the issue may or may not be occurring on the connected instance. You can however connect to the KUDU of a specific instance using my previous post here: <a title="https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2016/11/21/azure-app-service-how-to-connect-to-the-kudu-site-of-a-specific-instance/" href="https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/kaushal/2016/11/21/azure-app-service-how-to-connect-to-the-kudu-site-of-a-specific-instance/">How to connect to the Kudu site of a specific instance</a></font></div> <li> <div align="left"><font size="2">The downloading of the memory dump will contribute towards the outbound bandwidth of the App service plan. For more details refer: </font><a href="http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/pricing/details/data-transfers/"><font size="2">http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/pricing/details/data-transfers/</font></a></div> <li> <div align="left"><font size="2">When the memory dump is being written, the process remains in a frozen state for the entire duration of operation. So this impacts the application’s availability.</font></div> <li> <div align="left"><font size="2">You can compress the memory dump via <strong>7zip</strong> which is availably by default on Azure App Service instances. You can run the following command:</font></div></li></ul> <blockquote> <p align="left"><font style="background-color: #cccccc" size="2" face="Consolas">D:\home\Logfiles\Dumps&gt;D:\7zip\7za.exe a <strong>MemoryDumps</strong>.zip *.dmp</font></p> <p align="left"><font style="background-color: #cccccc" size="2">NOTE: Compression consumes CPU cycles, so you may want to re-consider when running this on a <strong>Small </strong>sized instance</font></p> <p align="left"><a href="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image63.png"><img title="image" style="border-left-width: 0px;border-right-width: 0px;border-bottom-width: 0px;padding-top: 0px;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="image" src="https://msdnshared.blob.core.windows.net/media/2017/05/image_thumb66.png" width="781" height="491"></a></p></blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
